required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Electromyography and Acceleromyography in Ventilated ICU Patients
clinical_study.official_title: The Effectiveness of Electromyographic- and Acceleromyographic-based Monitors in Diagnosing Pre-existing Train-of-four Fade in Ventilated ICU Patients

brief_summary.textblock: In intensive care unit (ICU) patients who are mechanically ventilated for a longer period of time, there might be a difference in accuracy and performance of neuromuscular transmission monitoring [as measured by the train-of-four (TOF)%] due to a pre-existing TOF fade, correlated to some form of acquired muscle weakness. The investigators therefore propose to search for and compare the optimal monitoring techniques (acceleromyography vs. electromyography) and the optimal muscle monitoring site (peripheral-adductor pollicis vs. central-corrugator supercilii) in ICU patients who require prolonged mechanical ventilation.

detailed_description.textblock:
The following neuromuscular transmission monitors will be used in the study: an electromyography-based monitor (TetraGraph, Senzime AB, Uppsala, Sweden) and two devices that are the newer generation of quantitative monitoring using three-dimensional acceleromyographic technology: Stimpod (Xavant Technology, Pretoria, South Africa) and TofScan (IDmed, Marseilles, France), both of which require minimal setup for use.
The stimulation pattern of both ulnar and facial nerves will be train-of-four (TOF) delivered every 1 minute, and the mean of three consecutive measurements will be calculated as the TOF% for that patient. Patients will be tested every 24 hrs, once a day, at the same time, over the 72 hrs the study will take place in the ICU.

clinical_study.why_stopped: Application of monitoring tools seemed inappropriate in ICU patients who were ventilated during a prolonged period.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Twenty mechanically ventilated ICU patients: the investigators will compare the mean TOF% between three different measurement techniques in 20 mechanically ventilated ICU patients: 1/electromyographic neuromuscular transmission monitoring at the hand muscle - 2/acceleromyographic neuromuscular transmission monitoring at the hand muscle - 3/acceleromyographic neuromuscular transmission monitoring at the eyebrow muscle; and the investigators will determine how the three TOF% values vary in each individual patient.

primary_outcome.measure: pre-existing neuromuscular fade (TOF% <90), correlated to some form of ICU acquired muscle weakness, in ICU patients mechanically ventilated for more than 72 hrs.
primary_outcome.time_frame: 72 hours of study period in ICU
primary_outcome.description: to find whether any patients show any pre-existing neuromuscular fade or develop such weakness over the 72 hours of study period in ICU

secondary_outcome.measure: fade (TOF% <90) difference between central (corrugator supercilii) and peripheral (adductor pollicis) muscles in ICU patients who require prolonged mechanical ventilation.
secondary_outcome.time_frame: 72 hours of study period in ICU
secondary_outcome.description: to compare the development of fade (if any develops) between central and peripheral muscles over the 72 hours of study period in ICU

other_outcome.measure: optimal monitor for use in the ICU setting
other_outcome.time_frame: 72 hours of study period in ICU
other_outcome.description: to determine the TOF% repeatability of the three monitors, establishing the optimal monitor for use in the ICU setting

arm_group.arm_group_label: electromyographic NMT monitoring at the hand
arm_group.description: In 20 mechanically ventilated ICU patients, TOF measurements will be performed every 24 hrs, once a day, at the same time, over the 72 hrs the study will take place in the ICU.

arm_group.arm_group_label: acceleromyographic NMT monitoring at the hand
arm_group.description: In 20 mechanically ventilated ICU patients, TOF measurements will be performed every 24 hrs, once a day, at the same time, over the 72 hrs the study will take place in the ICU.

arm_group.arm_group_label: acceleromyographic NMT monitoring at the eyebrow
arm_group.description: In 20 mechanically ventilated ICU patients, TOF measurements will be performed every 24 hrs, once a day, at the same time, over the 72 hrs the study will take place in the ICU.

intervention.description: The investigators will determine how the TOF% values vary in each individual patient, over time, in ICU.
intervention.arm_group_label: acceleromyographic NMT monitoring at the eyebrow
acceleromyographic NMT monitoring at the hand
electromyographic NMT monitoring at the hand

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 yr. old or older
- expected to require mechanical ventilation for more than 72 hrs
Exclusion Criteria:
- degenerative neurological disease
- receive drugs interfering with NMT (e.g., aminoglycosides or magnesium)

reference.citation: Naguib M, Brull SJ, Johnson KB. Conceptual and technical insights into the basis of neuromuscular monitoring. Anaesthesia. 2017 Jan;72 Suppl 1:16-37. doi: 10.1111/anae.13738. Review.

Cammu G, Neyens E, Coddens J, Van Praet F, De Decker K. Postoperative residual curarisation is still an issue when weaning patients in intensive care following cardiac surgery. Anaesth Intensive Care. 2018 Nov;46(6):634-636.
